title: Memory Test
text:
I am curious how long LLMs can hold onto user input.
To test this I will tell the LLM my favorite color (in this case dark green). Then I will tell it other information about myself like my age, favorite food, etc… before again asking the LLM what my favorite color is. I am going to increase the number of facts about myself to see where it will cap out and forget that my favorite color is dark green. I recognize that part of this constraint is the number of tokens I provide an LLM to remember (that is to say that a 100 word prompt in between would likely have more of an impact than a five word prompt), however for the purpose of this experiment I will only be counting based on the number of “facts” that I provide the LLM.
This relevant as when asking simple questions most LLMs can provide a response in the context of their trianing, but one of the more powerful use cases is when it can easily interact wiht user provided information. This is what makes it so powerful when drafting documents or code.


GPT4o - 3 Facts

GPT 4o correctly remembered that my favorite color was dark green after 3 facts.
GPT4o - 6 Facts

GPT 4o correctly remembered that my favorite color was dark green after 3 facts.
GPT4o - 12 Facts

GPT 4o correctly remembered that my favorite color was dark green after 12 facts. (Note that this is a different chat despite the image continuing).
GPT4o - 50 Facts

GPT 4o did not remember my favorite color after 50 facts. (Note that this is a different chat despite the image continuing).

title: Memory Test
text:
I am curious how long LLMs can hold onto user input.
To test this I will tell the LLM my favorite color (in this case dark green). GPT 4o correctly remembered that my favorite color was dark green after 3 facts.
GPT4o - 6 Facts

GPT 4o correctly remembered that my favorite color was dark green after 3 facts.
GPT4o - 12 Facts

GPT 4o correctly remembered that my favorite color was dark green after 12 facts. (Note that this is a different chat despite the image continuing).
GPT4o - 50 Facts

GPT 4o did not remember my favorite color after 50 facts. (Note that this is a different chat despite the image continuing).

title: Memory Test
text:
Takeaways
It is worth noting that initially GPT did a great job at remembering this simple fact after preventing it with a few number of facts, but as that number grew, at some point it was not able to remeber the intial piece of information. My understanding is that this is because there is memory that GPT uses that will run out at a certain point. I would also imagine (as noted above) that the length of the input and information GPT has to remember would impact how many messages can pass while GPT retains this information - which at a certain point is system design more than anything else.

title: LLM’s Drawing Words
text:
One of the areas that I have noticed LLMs to be particularly weak in is specific image generation. These diffusion models perform great when given an abstract task like “draw a cat in the middle of space”:

We can clearly see that it creatively comes up with a cat (an American cat at that) in vivid detail. We could specify more instruction, like a different art form or change a detail of the cat. However this is where LLMs perfomance in image generation seem to drop off. When tasked with creating more finite images that are seemingly simple - I have found that LLMs tend to create blurry images with mistakes. We can explore this poor perfomance by asking Dalle to generate images containing words that are increasingly complex.

title: LLM’s Drawing Words
text:
One of the areas that I have noticed LLMs to be particularly weak in is specific image generation. These diffusion models perform great when given an abstract task like “draw a cat in the middle of space”:

We can clearly see that it creatively comes up with a cat (an American cat at that) in vivid detail. We could specify more instruction, like a different art form or change a detail of the cat. However this is where LLMs perfomance in image generation seem to drop off. When tasked with creating more finite images that are seemingly simple - I have found that LLMs tend to create blurry images with mistakes. We can explore this poor perfomance by asking Dalle to generate images containing words that are increasingly complex.

title: LLM’s Drawing Words
section: “Generate an image with the word CAT”
text:
“Generate an image with the word CAT”

While this is techincally correct, it seems to have jumped to doing an artistic rendering of the word CAT. We can try to specify things a bit more to recieve the desired output.

title: LLM’s Drawing Words
section: “Generate a plain image with the word CAT (the word should be black with a simple white background)”
text:
“Generate a plain image with the word CAT (the word should be black with a simple white background)”

Here we were able to obtain the black word - but the rest of the smaller letters beneath the word CAT look like an eye exam. It is also important to note that some of those smaller letters seem to be smudged or cut off. At this point, maybe if we give some more specification around what we want, we can get the proper result.

title: LLM’s Drawing Words
section: “Generate a plain image with the word CAT (the word should be black with a simple white background). There should be no other letters in the image. The goal is to mimic a black piece of paper only the word CAT. You are not an artist.”
text:
“Generate a plain image with the word CAT (the word should be black with a simple white background). There should be no other letters in the image. The goal is to mimic a black piece of paper only the word CAT. You are not an artist.”

This time around we can see that this is far closer to the result that we want, but it isn’t exactly right. There is an odd grey boarder that was not requested. At this point - maybe we should ask Chat GPT 4o what the best image generation prompt is:

Let’s try it:

title: LLM’s Drawing Words
section: “A plain white background with the word ‘CAT’ in bold black text, centered. No other elements, decorations, or details.”
text:
“A plain white background with the word ‘CAT’ in bold black text, centered. No other elements, decorations, or details.”

This did the trick! It seems that the exact prompting with Dalle matters the most. At this point it begs more of a UI question with AI that if text to image if meant to be widely accisble, how can an image generation interface be better suited for a layman user? Maybe it would be better to provide users with a more guided experience, such as preset templates for common requests or a more interactive prompt refinement system - instead of requiring users to perfectly craft a text prompt.
In the future when trying to generate an image, it might be best to just ask an LLM what the best way to do this is!

title: Can ChatGPT Replace a Counsler?
text:
One of the fears that many have is that AI will take their job. They fear that one day we will wake up and GenAI will be able to take the job of every Software Engineer, Accountant, Business Analyst - anything with code of a spreadsheet. However some feel that they will not be touched at all by the AI revolution - Postmen, Plumbers, Construction workers - anyone who works in the “real world”. There are others who have confidence but should perhaps be less sure - like Psychologists or Counslers. Today I will explore how effective Chat GPT 4o is at when I share that my mental health is not great (something that I will note is purely for expirmentation purposes.


Below you will see that I: - Share my inital thoughts and feelings - Respond to any questions / provide more detail if needed - Then ask what I should do going forward
I am curious if ChatGPT will try to tackle the issue head on on or if GPT will recomend professional (non-AI) help at any point.

title: Can ChatGPT Replace a Counsler?

Below you will see that I: - Share my inital thoughts and feelings - Respond to any questions / provide more detail if needed - Then ask what I should do going forward
I am curious if ChatGPT will try to tackle the issue head on on or if GPT will recomend professional (non-AI) help at any point.

title: Can ChatGPT Replace a Counsler?
text:
Conversation
You said: Hi! I am not feeling so great today.
ChatGPT said: Hey Logan, I’m sorry to hear that. Rough day, or just not feeling 100%? Want to talk about it, or would you rather just chat about something fun to take your mind off things?
You said: I’ll talk about it a bit - I just had a really tough day, there was so much going on between classes, work, and dealing with others.
ChatGPT said: That sounds really overwhelming, Logan. Juggling classes, work, and dealing with people all at once can be exhausting. I can imagine it feels like there’s barely any room to breathe.
Was there something specific that made today extra tough, or was it just everything piling up at once?
You said: I think it was just everything piling up at once.
ChatGPT said: Yeah, that makes sense. When everything stacks up like that, even small things can feel way heavier. It’s frustrating when there’s no clear break to catch your breath.
Do you have anything coming up—like a free evening, a small break, or even just a quiet moment—where you can take a step back and reset? Or do you feel like the pressure’s still going to keep building?
You said: Yeah I will hopefully have a break during the weekend - then maybe something fun will happen.
ChatGPT said: That’s good to hear—you definitely deserve a break. Maybe you can plan something small to look forward to, even if it’s just a chill night, watching a movie, or doing something you enjoy.
If you want, we can brainstorm something fun to do this weekend, or I can just be here to chat and take your mind off things for a bit. Whatever helps!
You said: What ideas do you have - how can avoid this in the future?
ChatGPT said: For the weekend, it depends on what kind of break you need. Here are a few ideas based on different ways you might want to recharge:

Low-effort relaxation: Watch a movie, play a casual game, or go for a walk somewhere nice. Something that doesn’t require much thinking but lets you reset.
Social but stress-free: Hang out with friends in a way that doesn’t add pressure—maybe a board game night, getting food, or just vibing somewhere.
Something new/exciting: If you want to shake things up, you could try a new activity—an escape room, a new restaurant, or a random event happening near you.
Physical reset: If you feel burnt out, something like going to the gym, playing a sport, or even just stretching and getting fresh air could help.

How to Avoid This in the Future It’s tough, but here are a few ways to keep things from piling up too much:

Preemptively block off time for breaks – Even if you’re super busy, scheduling small breaks (even 10-15 mins) can stop things from spiraling.
Set ‘off-limits’ hours – A time at night where you stop working and let your mind rest. No school, no work, just chill time. Prioritize what actually matters – When everything feels urgent, it’s easy to stress over things that don’t deserve it. If you can, let go of the smaller stuff.
Delegate or push back where possible – If you’re taking on too much at once, is there anything you can shift around or ask for help with?
Check in with yourself sooner – If you feel stress building mid-week, take a step back instead of letting it pile up to breaking point.
What do you think? Do any of these feel doable, or is there something specific that usually pushes you over the edge?

You said: Yes this all helps! Thank you so much!
ChatGPT said: I’m really glad to hear that it helped! It sounds like you’re finding some good ways to take a breather, and I hope your weekend break brings you the recharge you need. Remember, it’s totally okay to prioritize yourself when things get overwhelming. If you ever want to chat more or brainstorm additional ideas, I’m here for you. Take care!

Takeways
Overall ChatGPT did a solid job at providing something to talk to and recenter my attention. I did find it interesting that it kept throwing things back onto me to push the conversation forward - I had to prompt it to give specific advice. FWIW - I think that LLMS perform better as you give more information - maybe I should have selected a more specific situation.
I found it interesting that ChatGPT did not recomend professional help at any point. I think that there is great promise for the ChatGPT to be a mental health first responder of sorts - especially as LLMs are applied to voices / humanoids to be more personal.

title: About
text: About this blog

title: TESTING AGAIN
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple…
But it is possible you first said green (don’t worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It’s a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | — | — | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get’s it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. 🟪

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I’ll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Humanity’s Last Exam Overview
text:
Benchmarking for LLMs is like standarardized testing to compare models. By having models do the same set of tasks or answer the same set of questions, we can see how they perform against eachother. The idea of benchmarking is placing a relative place for compaision and exists in almost all disciplines.
The benchmark that we will look at today, Humanity’s Last Exam (HLE), is an exam comprised of 3,000 difficult out of context questions from a variety of fields including, mathematics, humanities, and the natural sciences. The exam is multimodel - with some questions having images and others being purely text-based.
For context of the difficult of the exam see the below image of various model’s perfomance on the HLE benchmark:



We can see that no model is performing well on the bench mark (with the max being a 13 percent accuracy). Knowing this we can test some of these sample questions on GPT to see how it performs.















We should note that the answers are not provided to these questions (as this would potentially leak them to be trained by an LLM) so for now we will have to use guess ourselves if this is infact the correct response (likely not as we can see above). This benchmark will serve as a good indicator for the progress of LLMs. That is to say that if a model is able to perform well on such an assessment that it has been exposed to such a wide range of material that it is able to answer even the most obscurley difficult domain specific questions correctly. For some, HLE serves as the final indicator of AGI, while for others it is just another in a long line of benchmarks.
